channel.title: Comments on: Palaeontologists Don't Always See Eye To Eye

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/palaeontologists-dont-always-see-eye-to-eye/#comment-48">Andy Farke</a>.
Ah yes, good point! I should have distinguished more between Editors/Reviewers and Publishers. I acknowledge that often Editors provide invaluable assistance in manuscript improvements, but it appears in this case, they missed out quite a bit as otherwise these comments wouldn't be so challenging! Maybe I should get something actually published first though before being too critical.. :p
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Andy Farke.

Ah yes, good point! I should have distinguished more between Editors/Reviewers and Publishers. I acknowledge that often Editors provide invaluable assistance in manuscript improvements, but it appears in this case, they missed out quite a bit as otherwise these comments wouldn’t be so challenging! Maybe I should get something actually published first though before being too critical.. :p

item.title: By: Andy Farke
item.dc:creator: Andy Farke
item.description: Just one minor critique of your closing few sentences - without being able to view the original submitted version of the paper, we actually have no idea how much the initial reviewers did (or did not) improve the manuscript. I can confidently say that my own published work has been improved by pre-publication review (with the improvements ranging from quite minor to major). Of course, the journals themselves usually add little value (other than a citeable venue and pretty layout - content is strictly between me, the reviewers, and the volunteer editors)!
item.content:encoded: Just one minor critique of your closing few sentences – without being able to view the original submitted version of the paper, we actually have no idea how much the initial reviewers did (or did not) improve the manuscript. I can confidently say that my own published work has been improved by pre-publication review (with the improvements ranging from quite minor to major). Of course, the journals themselves usually add little value (other than a citeable venue and pretty layout – content is strictly between me, the reviewers, and the volunteer editors)!
